messages.content: do you answer some question? on how to use microsoft Azure
Yes, I can help you with questions related to using Microsoft Azure. What specific question do you have?

You have an Azure subscription that includes the following resources:

VNet1, a virtual network

Subnet1, a subnet in VNet1

WebApp1, a web app application service

NSG1, a network security group

You create an application security group named ASG1.

Which resource can use ASG1?

Select only one answer.

A: VNet1

B: Subnet1

C: WebApp1

D: NSG1

The correct answer is B: Subnet1. 

Application Security Groups (ASGs) are used to group virtual machines and define network security policies based on those groups. ASGs can be used in combination with Network Security Groups (NSGs) to define more granular network security policies. 

In this scenario, ASG1 can be associated with Subnet1 to define network security policies that apply to the virtual machines within that subnet.

You recently create an Azure virtual machine standard backup policy.

You need to configure a retention period for virtual machine instant recovery snapshots.

What is the maximum number of days that can be set for the retention period?

The maximum number of days that can be set for the retention period of virtual machine instant recovery snapshots in an Azure VM backup policy is 2 days. 

Instant recovery snapshots are used to quickly restore a virtual machine to a known good state in case of a failure. These snapshots are stored in a separate storage account and are retained for a short period of time to minimize storage costs. The maximum retention period for instant recovery snapshots is 2 days, after which they are automatically deleted.

You have an Azure subscription.

You plan to run a data warehouse in an Azure virtual machine named VM1.

You need to ensure that VM1 is optimized for running a data warehouse.

Which VM type should you use for VM1?

Select only one answer.

Option A: General purpose (D-Series)

Option B: Compute optimized (F-Series)

Option C: Memory optimized (M-Series)

Option D: Storage optimized (Ls-Series)

Option E: High performance computing (H-Series)

The correct answer is C: Memory optimized (M-Series).

M-Series VMs are optimized for memory-intensive workloads such as data warehousing, in-memory analytics, and other memory-intensive enterprise applications. These VMs offer the highest memory-to-CPU ratio available in the Azure VM family, making them an ideal choice for running a data warehouse. 

F-Series VMs are optimized for compute-intensive workloads and may not provide sufficient memory for a data warehouse. D-Series VMs are general-purpose VMs that are suitable for a wide range of workloads but may not provide the high memory capacity required for a data warehouse. Ls-Series VMs are optimized for storage-intensive workloads and may not offer the memory capacity required for a data warehouse. H-Series VMs are optimized for high performance computing workloads and may not be necessary for a data warehouse.

You have an Azure subscription.

You plan to use fault domains.

From which Azure resource can you configure the fault domains?

Select only one answer.

Option A: Virtual machine

Option B: Virtual machine scale set

Option C: Availability set

Option D: Virtual network

The correct answer is C: Availability set.

Fault domains are used to ensure high availability of applications by distributing virtual machines across different physical hardware within an Azure datacenter. An availability set is a logical grouping of two or more virtual machines that are deployed across multiple fault domains and update domains. 

When you create an availability set, you can specify the number of fault domains you want to use. The number of fault domains determines how many physical servers your virtual machines are spread across. By configuring your virtual machines to use different fault domains, you can ensure that your application remains available even if one of the physical servers fails.

Therefore, fault domains can be configured from an availability set in Azure.

You have an Azure subscription and an availability set named AS1 that has 5 update domains.

You deploy 27 virtual machines to AS1.

After a planned update, what is the minimum number of virtual machines that are available?

Select only one answer.

Option A: 14

Option B: 20

Option C: 21

Option D: 22

Option E: 26

The correct answer is C: 21.

In an availability set with 5 update domains, when a planned update is performed, only one update domain is updated at a time. This ensures that at least one update domain is always available for your virtual machines. 

To calculate the minimum number of virtual machines that will be available after a planned update, you need to first determine how many update domains are required for each virtual machine to be updated. In this case, there are 27 virtual machines and 5 update domains, so each update domain will contain 6 virtual machines with one update domain containing only 3 virtual machines.

During the update process, the update domains will be updated one after the other, starting with update domain 1. This means that at any point in time during the update process, the number of virtual machines available will be the total number of virtual machines in all update domains up to and including the current update domain being updated.

So, after the update of the first update domain, the number of available virtual machines will be 21 (6 in update domain 1, 6 in update domain 2, 6 in update domain 3, and 3 in update domain 4). The same is true for the update of the second update domain. After the update of the third update domain, the number of available virtual machines will be 15 (6 in update domain 3 and 3 in each of update domains 1 and 2). Finally, after the update of the fourth update domain, the number of available virtual machines will be 9 (3 in each of update domains 1, 2, and 3). Once all update domains have been updated, all 27 virtual machines will be available again.

You have an Azure subscription named Sub1.

You plan to deploy a virtual machine scale set named VMSS1 in East US region. VMSS1 will have 8 instances.

What is the maximum number of availability zones that VMSS1 can use?

The maximum number of availability zones that a virtual machine scale set (VMSS) can use depends on the region where it is deployed. 

In the East US region, VMSS1 can use up to 3 availability zones. 

Availability zones are distinct physical locations within an Azure region that are engineered to be independent of one another, with separate power, cooling, and networking. Deploying virtual machines across multiple availability zones can help protect against datacenter-level failures and provide higher availability for your applications. 

When you create a VMSS, you can specify the number of zones you want to use. If you specify multiple zones, Azure will automatically distribute the virtual machines across those zones to ensure high availability.
In the East US region, VMSS1 can use up to ? availability zones.
In the East US region, VMSS1 can use up to 3 availability zones.

You have an Azure subscription that contains a user named User1, a resource group named RG1, and a virtual machine named VM1.

You enable a system-assigned managed identity for VM1.

To which identities can you assign the Reports Reader role?

Select only one answer.

Option A: User1 only

Option B: User1 and RG1 only

Option C: User1 and VM1 only

Option D: User1, RG1, and VM1

The correct answer is C: User1 and VM1 only.

When you enable a system-assigned managed identity for a virtual machine, Azure creates an identity for that virtual machine in Azure AD. This identity can be used to authenticate to Azure services that support Azure AD authentication, without the need for credentials in your code. 

To assign the Reports Reader role to a managed identity, you need to use Azure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). RBAC is used to manage access to Azure resources based on the roles assigned to users, groups, and services. 

In this scenario, the Reports Reader role can be assigned to both User1 and the managed identity of VM1. The resource group RG1 is not relevant in this case because RBAC is used to manage access to individual resources, not resource groups. Therefore, the correct answer is C: User1 and VM1 only.

You have an Azure AD tenant named contoso.com that contains a user named Ben Smith.

You configure a Password protection for contoso.com that includes the following Custom banned passwords settings:

Enforce custom list: Yes
Custom banned password list: Contoso
Which password can be used by Ben Smith?

Select only one answer.

Option A: FgRs01

Option B: C0nt0s0123

Option C: CONTOSO123

Option D: Conto123so

The correct answer is D: Conto123so.

When you enable a custom banned password list in Azure AD password protection, any passwords on the list cannot be used by users in the tenant. In this scenario, the custom banned password list includes the word "Contoso". 

Therefore, passwords that include the word "Contoso" in any form cannot be used, such as "C0nt0s0123" or "CONTOSO123". However, the password "Conto123so" is allowed because it does not include the word "Contoso" in its entirety.
